title-group.article-title: Performance analysis of cognitive relay sharing systems with bidirectional primary transmissions under Nakagami-m fading†

article-meta.aff: Discipline of Electrical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Indore, Madhya Pradesh 453552, India

fn.p: A preliminary version of some part of this paper has been presented at the International Conference on Signal Processing and Communications (SPCOM), IISc, Bangalore, India, June 2016.

abstract.p: This study investigates the performance of a cognitive relay sharing system (CRSS) wherein two primary users (PUs) exchange the information bidirectionally. The overall transmission in CRSS takes place using an amplify-and-forward-based multiple access broadcast protocol. Herein, besides assisting the transmission of secondary users, the relay also provides an aid for the bidirectional communication between PUs. In addition, the secondary system employs an opportunistic user scheduling with multiple destinations to further ameliorate the performance of secondary network. Here, by considering Nakagami-m fading channels, the authors derive novel closed-form expressions of outage probability (OP) and average error probability for both primary and secondary systems. Based on the derived expressions of OP, the authors also quantify the average system throughput. With bidirectional primary communications, the proposed CRSS offers higher spectral efficiency and incentivises the secondary communication through multiuser diversity. Finally, numerical and simulation results are provided for the validation of the theoretical analysis.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Cognitive radio has acquired significant research interest over past few years. This is owing to its capability to efficiently use the available spectrum resources in overcrowded wireless networks [1]. In a cognitive radio network, the secondary users (SUs) are allowed to share the spectrum licensed to primary users (PUs) using underlay, overlay, and interweave approaches [2]. In underlay approach, the SUs can access the licensed spectrum subject to satisfying the interference power constraints imposed by the PUs. In overlay approach, both PUs and SUs simultaneously share the spectrum by employing sophisticated signal processing and coding techniques. In interweave approach, SUs opportunistically utilise the white spaces of spectrum for transmission while ensuring no interference to the PUs communication. With its simplicity in implementation, the underlay approach has been widely investigated in the literature and we consider the same in our study.

On another front, cooperative relaying has been established as a potential paradigm to enhance the coverage and reliability of the wireless systems [3]. Thus far, several relaying techniques have been studied in the literature considering one-way relaying protocol [4–7]. However, compared with one-way relaying, the two-way relaying schemes have potential to improve spectral efficiency in bidirectional cognitive radio networks [8]. There are two major protocols for two-way relaying networks, namely two-phase multiple access broadcast (MABC) [9] and three-phase time division broadcast [10]. Recently, such relaying techniques have been incorporated to cognitive radio networks to extract performance gains with efficient spectrum utilisation in fading environments. The performance of subsequent cognitive relay networks has been extensively analysed in the literature (e.g. [11–18] and the references therein). However, the majority of these works have focused on allocation of the available relay resources to secondary communication system only.

More recently, cognitive relay sharing systems (CRSSs) have been studied [19–21] that permit a secondary relay to assist the primary as well as the secondary transmissions. Such kind of relaying infrastructure can be very useful essentially when the direct link between two end PUs is weak or absent (due to high shadowing or large separation) and thereby the direct communication between them is inefficacious. The performance analysis of CRSS has been carried out using decode-and-forward relaying in [19] and with amplify-and-forward (AF) relaying in [20, 21]. Common to these works is that the primary system has to support only one-way communication. In [22], a multistage coding scheme for two-way relaying-based CRSS has been studied. However, to the best of authors’ knowledge, the performance of underlay CRSS supporting bidirectional primary communications has not been yet investigated.

In this paper, we consider a CRSS where a secondary relay is being shared to facilitate two-way primary communications using AF-based MABC protocol. Specifically, we consider a pair of PUs using two-way relay functionality in conjunction with a secondary relay network having multiple SU destinations. Hereby, with MABC protocol, the two end-PUs communicate bidirectionally with each other and an SU source communicates with a best selected SU destination by using a common secondary relay. The direct link between SU source and SU destination is also present. For this overall set-up, we derive the closed-form expressions of outage probability (OP) and average error probability for both primary and secondary systems over Nakagami-m fading channels. Furthermore, with the help of derived outage expressions, we quantify the average system throughput to investigate the spectral efficiency of considered system. We also compare the performance of the two-way primary system for proposed CRSS with a direct transmission (DT) scheme and present useful insights.

This paper is organised as follows: In Section 2, we present the descriptions of CRSS model and obtain end-to-end signal to interference plus noise ratios (SINR) of various links which will be used in subsequent performance analysis. In Section 3, we analyse the performance of primary system by deriving the closed form expressions of OP and average error probability. Likewise, the performance analysis of secondary system is carried out in Section 4. In Section 5, we quantify the average system throughput offered by CRSS to delve into the spectral efficiency of system. Numerical and simulation results are provided in Section 6, and finally, the conclusions are presented in Section 7.

Notations: Throughout this paper, ${\opf E}\lpar \; \rpar $E() denotes the expectation and ${\cal C}_r^n = n!/r!\lpar n - r\rpar !$Crn=n!/r!(n−r)! represents the binomial coefficient. $\Upsilon \lpar \; \comma \; \; \rpar $Υ(,), $\Gamma \lpar \; \comma \; \; \rpar $Γ(,), and $\Gamma \lpar \; \rpar $Γ() represent, respectively, the lower incomplete, the upper incomplete, and the complete gamma functions [23, eq. 8.350]. $G_{p\comma q}^{m\comma n} \left[{ \cdot \left\vert {\matrix{ \cdot \cr \cdot \cr } } \right.} \right]$Gp,qm,n⋅⋅⋅ represents Meijer's G-function [23, eq. 9.301], ${\cal K}_\mu \lpar \; \rpar $Kμ() denotes the μth order modified Bessel function of the second kind [23, eq. 8.432.1], whereas ${\cal W}_{u\comma v}\lpar \; \rpar $Wu,v() represents the Whittaker function [23, eq. 9.222].

sec.title: System descriptions
sec.p:
We consider an underlay CRSS as shown in Fig. 1, where an SU source $C_s$Cs transmits its signal to multiple SU destinations $\lcub C_{d_n}\rcub _{n = 1}^N ${Cdn}n=1N with the aid of a secondary AF relay $C_r$Cr and also via direct path. Besides, the relay $C_r$Cr facilitates bidirectional communication between two PU transceivers $T_a$Ta and $T_b$Tb. This primary system may correspond to a cellular scenario wherein a reliable direct link between base station ($T_a$Ta) and mobile user ($T_b$Tb) is not feasible. Further, we assume that $T_a$Ta and $T_b$Tb are located far from the $\lcub C_{d_n}\rcub _{n = 1}^N ${Cdn}n=1N so that the direct interference from PUs’ transmissions at SU destinations is not present. Although the interference constraints from $T_a$Ta and $T_b$Tb account for the amplifying gain of $C_r$Cr. All the channels are assumed quasi-static, reciprocal, and subject to independent Nakagami-m fading. Each transmitting node operates in half-duplex mode. Let the channel between the primary transceiver $T_\imath $Tı and $C_r$Cr be denoted as $h_{\imath r}$hır, where $i \in \lcub a\comma \; b\rcub $i∈{a,b}. Similarly, the channels for the links $C_s - C_r$Cs−Cr, $C_s - C_{d_n}$Cs−Cdn, and $C_r - C_{d_n}$Cr−Cdn are designated as $h_{sr}$hsr, $h_{sd_n}$hsdn, and $h_{rd_n}$hrdn, respectively. All links are corrupted by additive white Gaussian noise (AWGN) with mean zero and variance unity. Fig. 1
System model for cognitive relay sharing network

The overall communication in CRSS takes place in two time phases using MABC protocol. In the first phase, nodes $T_a$Ta and $T_b$Tb transmit their respective signals $x_a$xa and $x_b$xb with equal power P, while $C_s$Cs transmits its signal $x_c$xc with power $P_c$Pc to the relay node $C_r$Cr. Thus, the received signal at the node $C_r$Cr can be given as
(1)
$$y_r = \sqrt P h_{ar}x_a + \sqrt P h_{br}x_b + \sqrt {P_c} h_{sr}x_c + n_r\comma \; \eqno\lpar 1\rpar $$yr=Pharxa+Phbrxb+Pchsrxc+nr,
where ${\opf E}\lcub \vert x_j\vert ^2\rcub = 1$E{|xj|2}=1, for $j \in \lcub a\comma \; b\comma \; c\rcub $j∈{a,b,c}, and $n_r$nr is the AWGN at $C_r$Cr. Note that, in (1), the interference from secondary transmission is assumed to be large when compared with the noise at $C_r$Cr and hence $n_r$nr can be ignored for the subsequent performance analysis of primary system. In the second phase, the relay first amplifies the combined signal in (1) with a gain $\beta $β and then broadcasts it to the nodes $T_a$Ta, $T_b$Tb, and $C_{d_n}$Cdn. As a result, the signals received at $T_a$Ta and $T_b$Tb can be expressed, respectively, as
(2)
$$y_a = \beta h_{ar}\lpar \sqrt P h_{ar}x_a + \sqrt P h_{br}x_b + \sqrt {P_c} h_{sr}x_c\rpar + n_a\comma \; \eqno\lpar 2\rpar $$ya=βhar(Pharxa+Phbrxb+Pchsrxc)+na,
(3)
$$y_b = \beta h_{br}\lpar \sqrt P h_{ar}x_a + \sqrt P h_{br}x_b + \sqrt {P_c} h_{sr}x_c\rpar + n_b\comma \; \eqno\lpar 3\rpar $$yb=βhbr(Pharxa+Phbrxb+Pchsrxc)+nb,
where $n_a$na and $n_b$nb are the AWGNs at the respective nodes. On applying self-interference cancellation, (2) and (3) can be written as
(4)
$$\tilde y_a = \beta h_{ar}\sqrt P h_{br}x_b + \beta h_{ar}\sqrt {P_c} h_{sr}x_c + n_a\comma \; \eqno\lpar 4\rpar $$y~a=βharPhbrxb+βharPchsrxc+na,
(5)
$$\tilde y_b = \beta h_{br}\sqrt P h_{ar}x_a + \beta h_{br}\sqrt {P_c} h_{sr}x_c + n_b.\eqno\lpar 5\rpar $$y~b=βhbrPharxa+βhbrPchsrxc+nb.
Nevertheless, the interference caused by SU transmission to the PUs should not exceed a predefined threshold Q. Hereby, as in [20], we impose the constraints ${\opf E}\lcub \lpar \beta \sqrt {P_c} h_{sr}x_c\rpar ^2\rcub \le Q/\vert h_{ar}\vert ^2$E{(βPchsrxc)2}≤Q/|har|2 and ${\opf E}\lcub \lpar \beta \sqrt {P_c} h_{sr}x_c\rpar ^2\rcub \le Q/\vert h_{br}\vert ^2$E{(βPchsrxc)2}≤Q/|hbr|2. Consequently, the variable gain $\beta $β can be controlled as
(6)
$$\beta ^2 = \displaystyle{Q \over {P_c\vert h_{sr}\vert ^2\max \lpar \vert h_{ar}\vert ^2\comma \; \vert h_{br}\vert ^2\rpar }}.\eqno\lpar 6\rpar $$β2=QPc|hsr|2max(|har|2,|hbr|2).
On invoking $\beta $β from (6) into (4) and (5), the resulting instantaneous SINRs at $T_a$Ta and $T_b$Tb can be expressed, respectively, as
(7)
$$\Lambda _{ba} = \displaystyle{{QP\vert h_{ar}\vert ^2\vert h_{br}\vert ^2} \over {QP_c\vert h_{ar}\vert ^2\vert h_{sr}\vert ^2 + P_c\vert h_{sr}\vert ^2\max \lpar \vert h_{ar}\vert ^2\comma \; \vert h_{br}\vert ^2\rpar }}\comma \; \eqno\lpar 7\rpar $$Λba=QP|har|2|hbr|2QPc|har|2|hsr|2+Pc|hsr|2max(|har|2,|hbr|2),
(8)
$$\Lambda _{ab} = \displaystyle{{QP\vert h_{br}\vert ^2\vert h_{ar}\vert ^2} \over {QP_c\vert h_{br}\vert ^2\vert h_{sr}\vert ^2 + P_c\vert h_{sr}\vert ^2\max \lpar \vert h_{ar}\vert ^2\comma \; \vert h_{br}\vert ^2\rpar }}.\eqno\lpar 8\rpar $$Λab=QP|hbr|2|har|2QPc|hbr|2|hsr|2+Pc|hsr|2max(|har|2,|hbr|2).
In the secondary system, the SU source $C_s$Cs communicates with a selected SU destination $C_{d_n}$Cdn via both the direct and the relay links. The received signals at $C_{d_n}$Cdn via the direct and relay links in first and second phases can be given, respectively, as
(9)
$$y_{sd_n} = \sqrt {P_c} h_{sd_n}x_c + n_{d_n}^{\lpar {\rm I}\rpar } \comma \; \eqno\lpar 9\rpar $$ysdn=Pchsdnxc+ndn(I),
(10)
$$\eqalign{y_{rd_n} & =\beta h_{rd_n}\sqrt {P_c} h_{sr}x_c + \beta h_{rd_n}\sqrt P h_{ar}x_a \cr & \quad + \beta h_{rd_n}\sqrt P h_{br}x_b + \beta h_{rd_n}n_r + n_{d_n}^{\lpar {\rm II}\rpar } \comma \; } \eqno\lpar 10\rpar $$yrdn=βhrdnPchsrxc+βhrdnPharxa+βhrdnPhbrxb+βhrdnnr+ndn(II),
where $n_{d_n}^{\lpar {\rm I}\rpar } $ndn(I) and $n_{d_n}^{\lpar {\rm II}\rpar } $ndn(II) are the respective AWGNs at $C_{d_n}$Cdn. From (10), one can observe that the signal received via relay at $C_{d_n}$Cdn also contains PUs’ signal components. As such, the interference caused by these PUs’ signals is detrimental for the performance of secondary system. Therefore, relying on multiuser decoding [24], we consider that these signals are successfully decoded at $C_{d_n}$Cdn so that the PUs interference can be cancelled out. Consequently, the SINRs via the direct link and the relay link (after removing PUs interference) at $C_{d_n}$Cdn, can be expressed, respectively, as
(11)
$$\Lambda _{sd_n} = P_c\vert h_{sd_n}\vert ^2\comma \; \eqno\lpar 11\rpar $$Λsdn=Pc|hsdn|2,
(12)
$$\Lambda _{rd_n} = \displaystyle{{QP_c\vert h_{rd_n}\vert ^2\vert h_{sr}\vert ^2} \over {Q\vert h_{rd_n}\vert ^2 + P_c\vert h_{sr}\vert ^2\max \lpar \vert h_{ar}\vert ^2\comma \; \vert h_{br}\vert ^2\rpar }}.\eqno\lpar 12\rpar $$Λrdn=QPc|hrdn|2|hsr|2Q|hrdn|2+Pc|hsr|2max(|har|2,|hbr|2).
For opportunistic scheduling, the best SU destination is considered to be selected based on $n^ \ast = \arg \mathop {\max }\nolimits_{n \in \lcub 1\comma \ldots \comma N\rcub } \lcub \Lambda _{sd_n}\rcub $n∗=argmaxn∈{1,…,N}⁡{Λsdn}.

Hereafter, we use $Y_{ar} = \vert h_{ar}\vert ^2$Yar=|har|2, $Y_{br} = \vert h_{br}\vert ^2$Ybr=|hbr|2, $Y_{sr} = \vert h_{sr}\vert ^2$Ysr=|hsr|2, $Y_{sd_n} = \vert h_{sd_n}\vert ^2$Ysdn=|hsdn|2, and $Y_{rd_n} = \vert h_{rd_n}\vert ^2$Yrdn=|hrdn|2 for notational simplicity. Furthermore, we assume that all N destinations are clustered together and thereby experience the same scale fading. Thus, the channel gains $Y_{ar}$Yar, $Y_{br}$Ybr, $Y_{sr}$Ysr, $Y_{sd_n}$Ysdn, and $Y_{rd_n}$Yrdn are Gamma random variables (RVs) with fading severity parameters $m_{ar}$mar, $m_{br}$mbr, $m_{sr}$msr, $m_{sd}$msd, and $m_{rd}$mrd, and average power levels $\Omega _{ar}$Ωar, $\Omega _{br}$Ωbr, $\Omega _{sr}$Ωsr, $\Omega _{sd}$Ωsd, and $\Omega _{rd}$Ωrd, respectively, for $n = 1\comma \; \ldots \comma \; N$n=1,…,N. The probability density function (PDF) and cumulative distribution function (CDF) of a Gamma RV X with parameters m and $\Omega $Ω are given, respectively, by $f_X\lpar x\rpar = \lpar m/\Omega \rpar ^m\lpar x^{m - 1}/\Gamma \lpar m\rpar \rpar {\rm e}^{ - mx/\Omega }$fX(x)=(m/Ω)m(xm−1/Γ(m))e−mx/Ω and $F_X\lpar x\rpar = \lpar 1/\Gamma \lpar m\rpar \rpar \Upsilon \lpar m\comma \; mx/\Omega \rpar $FX(x)=(1/Γ(m))Υ(m,mx/Ω).

sec.title: Performance analysis of primary system
sec.p: In this section, we conduct performance analysis for the primary system under Nakagami-m fading.

sec.title: Outage probability
sec.p:
A two-way relay system is said to be in outage if either of the two end-to-end SINRs falls below a certain threshold. Considering equal rate requirements at PUs, the OP of the primary system for a given threshold $\gamma _{{\rm th}}$γth can be formulated as
(13)
$${\cal P}_{{\rm out}}^{{\rm Pri}} \lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\rpar = {\rm Pr}\lsqb \min \lpar \Lambda _{ab}\comma \; \Lambda _{ba}\rpar \lt \gamma _{{\rm th}}\rsqb \comma \; \eqno\lpar 13\rpar $$PoutPri(γth)=Pr[min(Λab,Λba)<γth],
which can be re-written as
(14)
$$\eqalign{{\cal P}_{{\rm out}}^{{\rm Pri}} \lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\rpar & =\underbrace{{{\rm Pr}\lsqb \Lambda _{ba} \lt \gamma _{{\rm th}}\comma \; \Lambda _{ba} \lt \Lambda _{ab}\rsqb }}_{{\chi _{ab}^{{\rm Pri}} \lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\rpar }} \cr & \quad + \underbrace{{{\rm Pr}\lsqb \Lambda _{ab} \lt \gamma _{{\rm th}}\comma \; \Lambda _{ab} \lt \Lambda _{ba}\rsqb }}_{{\chi _{ba}^{{\rm Pri}} \lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\rpar }}\comma \; } \eqno\lpar 14\rpar $$PoutPri(γth)=Pr[Λba<γth,Λba<Λab]⏟χabPri(γth)+Pr[Λab<γth,Λab<Λba]⏟χbaPri(γth),
where $\Lambda _{ba}$Λba and $\Lambda _{ab}$Λab are SINRs as given in (7) and (8), respectively. Hereby, to compute the OP in (14), we need to obtain $\chi _{ab}^{{\rm Pri}} \lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\rpar $χabPri(γth) and $\chi _{ba}^{{\rm Pri}} \lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\rpar $χbaPri(γth). Therefore, we first derive $\chi _{ab}^{{\rm Pri}} \lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\rpar $χabPri(γth) in the following Lemma.

statement.label: Lemma 1
statement.p:
: $\chi _{ab}^{{\rm Pri}} \lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\rpar $χabPri(γth) in (14) is given by
(15)
$$\eqalign{\chi _{ab}^{{\rm Pri}} \lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\rpar & =\sum\limits_{p = 0}^{m_{ar} - 1} \sum\limits_{q = 0}^{m_{sr} - 1} \displaystyle{{\Gamma \lpar m_{br} + p + q\rpar } \over {p!q!\Gamma \lpar m_{br}\rpar }}\left({\displaystyle{{m_{sr}} \over {\Omega _{sr}{\tilde \gamma }_{{\rm th}}}}} \right)^q\left({\displaystyle{{m_{br}} \over {\Omega _{br}}}} \right)^{m_{br}} \cr & \quad \times \left({\displaystyle{{m_{ar}} \over {\Omega _{ar}}}} \right)^p\left({\displaystyle{{m_{ar}} \over {\Omega _{ar}}} + \displaystyle{{m_{br}} \over {\Omega _{br}}} + \displaystyle{{m_{sr}} \over {\Omega _{sr}{\tilde \gamma }_{{\rm th}}}}} \right)^{ - \lpar m_{br} + p + q\rpar }\comma \; } \eqno\lpar 15\rpar $$χabPri(γth)=∑p=0mar−1∑q=0msr−1Γ(mbr+p+q)p!q!Γ(mbr)msrΩsrγ~thqmbrΩbrmbr×marΩarpmarΩar+mbrΩbr+msrΩsrγ~th−(mbr+p+q),
where $\tilde \gamma _{{\rm th}}{\rm \triangleq }\lpar P_c/P\rpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\left({1 + \lpar 1/Q\rpar } \right)$γ~th≜(Pc/P)γth1+(1/Q).

statement.label: Proof
statement.p:
Based on the SINR in (7), one can observe that $\Lambda _{ba} \lt \Lambda _{ab}$Λba<Λab assimilates with $Y_{br} \lt Y_{ar}$Ybr<Yar. Hence, the $\chi _{ab}^{{\rm Pri}} \lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\rpar $χabPri(γth) can be expressed as
(16)
$$\chi _{ab}^{{\rm Pri}} \lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\rpar = {\rm Pr}\left[{Y_{sr} \gt \displaystyle{{Y_{br}} \over {{\tilde \gamma }_{{\rm th}}}}\comma \; Y_{br} \lt Y_{ar}} \right] \comma \eqno\lpar 16\rpar $$χabPri(γth)=PrYsr>Ybrγ~th,Ybr<Yar,
which (with involved dependence) can be evaluated as
(17)
$$\chi _{ab}^{{\rm Pri}} \lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\rpar = \int_0^\infty \bar F_{Y_{sr}}\left({\displaystyle{y \over {{\tilde \gamma }_{{\rm th}}}}} \right)\bar F_{Y_{ar}}\left(y \right)f_{Y_{br}}\lpar y\rpar \; {\rm d}y\comma \; \eqno\lpar 17\rpar $$χabPri(γth)=∫0∞F¯Ysryγ~thF¯YaryfYbr(y)dy,
wherein $\bar F_Y\lpar \; \rpar = 1 - F_Y\lpar \; \rpar $F¯Y()=1−FY() represents complementary CDF. Now, on substituting the required CDFs and PDF, and utilising the series form of gamma function [23, eq. 8.352.1], and performing the resulting integration (with the aid of [23, eq. 3.351.3]), we can arrive at the same expression as in (15).□

sec.p: Next, as done for $\chi _{ab}^{{\rm Pri}} \lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\rpar $χabPri(γth) in Lemma 1, the $\chi _{ba}^{{\rm Pri}} \lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\rpar $χbaPri(γth) can be readily evaluated and is equivalent to $\chi _{ab}^{{\rm Pri}} \lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\rpar $χabPri(γth) in (15) with indices $\lcub a\comma \; b\rcub ${a,b} interchanged.

Finally, using $\chi _{ab}^{{\rm Pri}} \lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\rpar $χabPri(γth) and $\chi _{ba}^{{\rm Pri}} \lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\rpar $χbaPri(γth), the OP for primary system ${\cal P}_{{\rm out}}^{{\rm Pri}} \lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\rpar $PoutPri(γth) in (14) can be computed. As such, based on (15), one can observe that the performance of primary system depends on the channel parameters of secondary $C_s - C_r$Cs−Cr link. Thereby, it can be deduced that for lower values of $\Omega _{sr}$Ωsr, i.e. when $C_s$Cs is located far away from $C_r$Cr, the performance of primary system improves. This is owing to the decrease in interference power level from the SU source transmission.

sec.title: Average error probability
sec.p:
The average error probability of the primary system for the considered CRSS can be evaluated using the CDF-based method as follows [25]:
(18)
$${\cal P}_e^{{\rm Pri}} = \displaystyle{\alpha \over 2}\sqrt {\displaystyle{\eta \over \pi }} \int_0^\infty \displaystyle{{\exp \lpar - \eta x\rpar } \over {\sqrt x }}F_{\Lambda _{{\rm eq}}}^{{\rm Pri}} \lpar x\rpar \; {\rm d}x\comma \; \eqno\lpar 18\rpar $$PePri=α2ηπ∫0∞exp⁡(−ηx)xFΛeqPri(x)dx,
where $\alpha $α and $\eta $η are the arbitrary constants evaluated based on the modulation schemes, e.g. $\alpha = 2$α=2 and $\eta = {\rm sin}\left({\pi /M} \right)^2$η=sinπ/M2 for M-ary phase shift keying (M-PSK). Here, $F_{\Lambda _{{\rm eq}}}^{{\rm Pri}} \lpar x\rpar $FΛeqPri(x) is CDF of equivalent SINR $\Lambda _{{\rm eq}}{\rm \triangleq }\min \lpar \Lambda _{ab}\comma \; \Lambda _{ba}\rpar $Λeq≜min(Λab,Λba), which can be directly obtained from (14) by replacing $\gamma _{{\rm th}}$γth with x, and is given by
(19)
$$F_{\Lambda _{{\rm eq}}}^{{\rm Pri}} \lpar x\rpar = \chi _{ab}^{{\rm Pri}} \lpar x\rpar + \chi _{ba}^{{\rm Pri}} \lpar x\rpar .\eqno\lpar 19\rpar $$FΛeqPri(x)=χabPri(x)+χbaPri(x).
Following this, ${\cal P}_e^{{\rm Pri}} $PePri in (18) can be written as
(20)
$$\eqalign{{\cal P}_e^{{\rm Pri}} & =\underbrace{{\displaystyle{\alpha \over 2}\sqrt {\displaystyle{\eta \over \pi }} \int_0^\infty \displaystyle{{\exp \lpar - \eta x\rpar } \over {\sqrt x }}\chi _{ab}^{{\rm Pri}} \lpar x\rpar \; {\rm d}x}}_{{{\cal P}_{e_{ab}}^{{\rm Pri}} }} \cr & \quad + \underbrace{{\displaystyle{\alpha \over 2}\sqrt {\displaystyle{\eta \over \pi }} \int_0^\infty \displaystyle{{\exp \lpar - \eta x\rpar } \over {\sqrt x }}\chi _{ba}^{{\rm Pri}} \lpar x\rpar \; {\rm d}x}}_{{{\cal P}_{e_{ba}}^{{\rm Pri}} }}\comma \; } \eqno\lpar 20\rpar $$PePri=α2ηπ∫0∞exp⁡(−ηx)xχabPri(x)dx⏟PeabPri+α2ηπ∫0∞exp⁡(−ηx)xχbaPri(x)dx⏟PebaPri,
where ${\cal P}_{e_{ab}}^{{\rm Pri}} $PeabPri is as derived in the following Lemma.

statement.label: Lemma 2
statement.p:
The ${\cal P}_{e_{ab}}^{{\rm Pri}} $PeabPri in (20) is given by
(21)
$$\eqalign{{\cal P}_{e_{ab}}^{{\rm Pri}} & =\displaystyle{\alpha \over {2\sqrt \pi }}\sum\limits_{p = 0}^{m_{ar} - 1} \sum\limits_{q = 0}^{m_{sr} - 1} \displaystyle{1 \over {\Gamma \lpar m_{br}\rpar p!q!}}\left({\displaystyle{{m_{br}} \over {\Omega _{br}}}} \right)^{m_{br}}\left({\displaystyle{{m_{ar}} \over {\Omega _{ar}}}} \right)^p \cr & \quad \times \left({\displaystyle{{m_{sr}\eta } \over {\Omega _{sr}{\tilde P}_c}}} \right)^{ - \lpar m_{br} + p\rpar }G_{2\comma 1}^{1\comma 2} \left[{\displaystyle{1 \over {\eta \tilde B}}\left\vert {\matrix{ {1/2 - {\tilde m}_{br}\comma \; 1 - {\tilde m}_{br} - q} \cr 0 \cr } } \right.} \right]\comma \; } \eqno\lpar 21\rpar $$PeabPri=α2π∑p=0mar−1∑q=0msr−11Γ(mbr)p!q!mbrΩbrmbrmarΩarp×msrηΩsrP~c−(mbr+p)G2,11,21ηB~1/2−m~br,1−m~br−q0,
where $\tilde P_c = \lpar P_c/P\rpar \left({1 + \lpar 1/Q\rpar } \right)$P~c=(Pc/P)1+(1/Q), $\tilde B = \lpar m_{sr}/\Omega _{sr}P_c\rpar /\left({\lpar m_{ar}/\Omega _{ar}\rpar + \lpar m_{br}/\Omega _{br}\rpar } \right)$B~=(msr/ΩsrPc)/(mar/Ωar)+(mbr/Ωbr), and $\tilde m_{br} = m_{br} + p$m~br=mbr+p.

statement.label: Proof
statement.p:
On inserting $\chi _{ab}^{{\rm Pri}} \lpar x\rpar $χabPri(x) from (15) in (19) and obtained result into (18), ${\cal P}_{e_{ab}}^{{\rm Pri}} $PeabPri can be written as
(22)
$$\eqalign{{\cal P}_{e_{ab}}^{{\rm Pri}} & =\displaystyle{\alpha \over 2}\sqrt {\displaystyle{\eta \over \pi }} \sum\limits_{p = 0}^{m_{ar} - 1} \sum\limits_{q = 0}^{m_{sr} - 1} \displaystyle{1 \over {\Gamma \lpar m_{br}\rpar p!q!}}\left({\displaystyle{{m_{br}} \over {\Omega _{br}}}} \right)^{m_{br}}\left({\displaystyle{{m_{ar}} \over {\Omega _{ar}}}} \right)^p \cr & \quad \times \left({\displaystyle{{m_{sr}} \over {\Omega _{sr}{\tilde P}_c}}} \right)^q\left({\displaystyle{{m_{ar}} \over {\Omega _{ar}}} + \displaystyle{{m_{br}} \over {\Omega _{br}}}} \right)^{ - \lpar m_{br} + p + q\rpar } \cr & \quad \times \int_0^\infty \displaystyle{{x^{\lpar m_{br} + p - 1/2\rpar }\exp \lpar - \eta x\rpar } \over {{\lpar x + \tilde B\rpar }^{\lpar m_{br} + p + q\rpar }}}\; {\rm d}x.} \eqno\lpar 22\rpar $$PeabPri=α2ηπ∑p=0mar−1∑q=0msr−11Γ(mbr)p!q!mbrΩbrmbrmarΩarp×msrΩsrP~cqmarΩar+mbrΩbr−(mbr+p+q)×∫0∞x(mbr+p−1/2)exp⁡(−ηx)(x+B~)(mbr+p+q)dx.
To compute the integral in (22), we express the integrand in term of Meijer's G-function. In particular, the term $1/\lpar x + \tilde B\rpar ^{\lpar m_{br} + p + q\rpar }$1/(x+B~)(mbr+p+q) can be expressed [26, eq. 30] as follows:
(23)
$$\eqalign{\displaystyle{1 \over {{\lpar x + \tilde B\rpar }^{{\tilde m}_{br} + q}}} & =\displaystyle{1 \over {{\tilde B}^{{\tilde m}_{br} + q}\Gamma \lpar {\tilde m}_{br} + q\rpar }} \cr & \quad \times G_{1\comma 1}^{1\comma 1} \left[{\displaystyle{x \over {\tilde B}}\left\vert {\matrix{ {1 - {\tilde m}_{br} - q} \cr 0 \cr } } \right.} \right].} \eqno\lpar 23\rpar $$1(x+B~)m~br+q=1B~m~br+qΓ(m~br+q)×G1,11,1xB~1−m~br−q0.
Then, inserting (23) in (22) and integrating the result using [23, eq. 7.813.1], we obtain the expression as given in (21).□

sec.p: Next, by following the same way as in Lemma 2, we can evaluate ${\cal P}_{e_{ba}}^{{\rm Pri}} $PebaPri in (18) which would be same as ${\cal P}_{e_{ab}}^{{\rm Pri}} $PeabPri in (22) with indices {a, b} interchanged.
Finally, plugging ${\cal P}_{e_{ba}}^{{\rm Pri}} $PebaPri and ${\cal P}_{e_{ab}}^{{\rm Pri}} $PeabPri into (20), the average error probability ${\cal P}_e^{{\rm Pri}} $PePri can be evaluated.

sec.title: Performance analysis of secondary system
sec.p: In what follows, we carry out the performance analysis for the secondary system under Nakagami-m fading.

sec.title: Outage probability
sec.p:
In the secondary system, the source $C_s$Cs transmits its message to the best selected SU destination $C_{d_{n^ \ast }}$Cdn∗ through direct and relay links in successive time phases. With selection cooperation at $C_{d_{n^ \ast }}$Cdn∗, the OP for a given threshold $\gamma _{{\rm th}}$γth is given by
(24)
$$\eqalign{{\cal P}_{{\rm out}}^{{\rm Sec}} \lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\rpar & ={\rm Pr}\left[{\max \left({\Lambda _{sd_{n^ \ast }}\comma \; \Lambda _{rd_{n^ \ast }}} \right)\lt \gamma _{{\rm th}}} \right]\cr & ={\rm Pr}\left[{\Lambda _{sd_{n^ \ast }} \lt \gamma _{{\rm th}}\comma \; \Lambda _{rd_{n^ \ast }} \lt \gamma _{{\rm th}}} \right]\comma \; } \eqno\lpar 24\rpar $$PoutSec(γth)=PrmaxΛsdn∗,Λrdn∗<γth=PrΛsdn∗<γth,Λrdn∗<γth,
which can be determined as
(25)
$${\cal P}_{{\rm out}}^{{\rm Sec}} \lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\rpar = \left[{F_{\Lambda _{sd_n}}\lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\rpar } \right]^NF_{\Lambda _{rd_n}}\lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\rpar .\eqno\lpar 25\rpar $$PoutSec(γth)=FΛsdn(γth)NFΛrdn(γth).
For evaluation of (25), we require the CDFs $F_{\Lambda _{sd_n}}\lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\rpar $FΛsdn(γth) and $F_{\Lambda _{rd_n}}\lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\rpar $FΛrdn(γth). First, by using (11), $F_{\Lambda _{sd_n}}\lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\rpar $FΛsdn(γth) can be given as
(26)
$$F_{\Lambda _{sd_n}}\lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\rpar = F_{Y_{sd_n}}\left({\displaystyle{{\gamma _{{\rm th}}} \over {P_c}}} \right)= \displaystyle{1 \over {\Gamma \lpar m_{sd}\rpar }}\Upsilon \left({m_{sd}\comma \; \displaystyle{{m_{sd}\gamma _{{\rm th}}} \over {\Omega _{sd}P_c}}} \right).\eqno\lpar 26\rpar $$FΛsdn(γth)=FYsdnγthPc=1Γ(msd)Υmsd,msdγthΩsdPc.
Then, to derive $F_{\Lambda _{rd_n}}\lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\rpar $FΛrdn(γth) using (12), we can represent
(27)
$$F_{\Lambda _{rd_n}}\lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\rpar = {\rm Pr}\left[{\displaystyle{{QP_cY_{sr}Y_{rd_n}} \over {QY_{rd_n} + P_cY_{sr}\max \lpar Y_{ar}\comma \; Y_{br}\rpar }} \lt \gamma _{{\rm th}}} \right]\comma \; \eqno\lpar 27\rpar $$FΛrdn(γth)=PrQPcYsrYrdnQYrdn+PcYsrmax(Yar,Ybr)<γth,
which can be re-expressed as
(28)
$$\eqalign{F_{\Lambda _{rd_n}}\lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\rpar & =\underbrace{{{\rm Pr}\left[{\displaystyle{{QP_cY_{sr}Y_{rd_n}} \over {QY_{rd_n} + P_cY_{sr}Y_{ar}}} \lt \gamma _{{\rm th}}\comma \; Y_{br} \lt Y_{ar}} \right]}}_{{\chi _{ab}^{{\rm Sec}} \lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\rpar }} \cr & \quad + \underbrace{{{\rm Pr}\left[{\displaystyle{{QP_cY_{sr}Y_{rd_n}} \over {QY_{rd_n} + P_cY_{sr}Y_{br}}} \lt \gamma _{{\rm th}}\comma \; Y_{ar} \lt Y_{br}} \right]}}_{{\chi _{ba}^{{\rm Sec}} \lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\rpar }}.} \eqno\lpar 28\rpar $$FΛrdn(γth)=PrQPcYsrYrdnQYrdn+PcYsrYar<γth,Ybr<Yar⏟χabSec(γth)+PrQPcYsrYrdnQYrdn+PcYsrYbr<γth,Yar<Ybr⏟χbaSec(γth).
Hereby, to evaluate $F_{\Lambda _{rd_n}}\lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\rpar $FΛrdn(γth) in (28), we need to obtain $\chi _{ab}^{{\rm Sec}} \lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\rpar $χabSec(γth) and $\chi _{ba}^{{\rm Sec}} \lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\rpar $χbaSec(γth). Let us proceed to derive $\chi _{ab}^{{\rm Sec}} \lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\rpar $χabSec(γth) in the following Lemma.

statement.label: Lemma 3
statement.p:
The function $\chi _{ab}^{{m Sec}} \lpar \gamma _{{m th}}par $χabSec(γth) in (28) is given by
(29)
$$\chi _{ab}^{{m Sec}} \lpar \gamma _{{m th}}par = \chi _{ab}^1 \lpar \gamma _{{m th}}par + \chi _{ab}^2 \lpar \gamma _{{m th}}par \comma \; \eqno\lpar 29par $$χabSec(γth)=χab1(γth)+χab2(γth),
where $\chi _{ab}^1 \lpar \gamma _{{m th}}par $χab1(γth) and $\chi _{ab}^2 \lpar \gamma _{{m th}}par $χab2(γth) are given, respectively, as
(30)
$$\eqalign{\chi _{ab}^1 \lpar \gamma _{{m th}}par & =\sum\limits_{
u = 0}^1 \sum\limits_{p = 0}^{
u \lpar m_{rd} - 1par } \sum\limits_{t = 0}^p \sum\limits_{s = 0}^{m_{sr} - 1} \sum\limits_{\kappa = 0}^1 \sum\limits_{l = 0}^{\kappa \lpar m_{br} - 1par } \lpar - 1par ^{
u + \kappa } \cr & \quad 	imes \displaystyle{{\omega _p^
u \omega _l^\kappa {\cal C}_t^p {\cal C}_s^{m_{sr} - 1} } \over {\Gamma \lpar m_{sr}par \Gamma \lpar m_{ar}par }}{m e}^{ - m_{sr}\gamma _{{m th}}/\Omega _{sr}P_c}\left({\displaystyle{{m_{sr}} \over {\Omega _{sr}}}} ight)^{m_{sr}}\left({\displaystyle{{\gamma _{{m th}}} \over {P_c}}} ight)^{s + t} \cr & \quad 	imes \left({\displaystyle{{m_{rd}\gamma _{{m th}}} \over {\Omega _{rd}Q}}} ight)^p\left({\displaystyle{{	ilde 
u \Omega _{sr}} \over {m_{sr}}}} ight)^{{	ilde m}_{sr}/2}\left({\displaystyle{{m_{br}} \over {\Omega _{br}}}} ight)^l\left({\displaystyle{{m_{ar}} \over {\Omega _{ar}}}} ight)^{m_{ar}} \cr & \quad 	imes {	ilde \kappa }^{ - 	ilde p/2}{m e}^{	ilde 
u m_{sr}/2	ilde \kappa \Omega _{sr}}\Gamma \lpar {	ilde m}_{ar}par \Gamma \lpar {	ilde m}_{sr} + {	ilde m}_{ar}par \left({\displaystyle{{	ilde 
u m_{sr}} \over {\Omega _{sr}}}} ight)^{ - 1/2} \cr & \quad 	imes {\cal W}_{ - 	ilde p/2\comma {	ilde m}_{sr}/2}\left({\displaystyle{{	ilde 
u \Omega _{sr}} \over {	ilde \kappa m_{sr}}}} ight)\comma \; } \eqno\lpar 30par $$χab1(γth)=∑ν=01∑p=0ν(mrd−1)∑t=0p∑s=0msr−1∑κ=01∑l=0κ(mbr−1)(−1)ν+κ×ωpνωlκCtpCsmsr−1Γ(msr)Γ(mar)e−msrγth/ΩsrPcmsrΩsrmsrγthPcs+t×mrdγthΩrdQpν~Ωsrmsrm~sr/2mbrΩbrlmarΩarmar×κ~−p~/2eν~msr/2κ~ΩsrΓ(m~ar)Γ(m~sr+m~ar)ν~msrΩsr−1/2×W−p~/2,m~sr/2ν~Ωsrκ~msr,
and
(31)
$$\eqalign{\chi _{ab}^2 \lpar \gamma _{{m th}}par & =\sum\limits_{k = 0}^1 \sum\limits_{n = 0}^{k\lpar m_{sr} - 1par } \sum\limits_{j = 0}^1 \sum\limits_{l = 0}^{j\lpar m_{br} - 1par } \displaystyle{{{\lpar - 1par }^{k + j}\omega _n^k \omega _l^j } \over {\Gamma \lpar m_{ar}par }} \cr & \quad 	imes \left({\displaystyle{{m_{ar}} \over {\Omega _{ar}}}} ight)^{m_{ar}}\left({\displaystyle{{m_{br}} \over {\Omega _{br}}}} ight)^l\left({\displaystyle{{m_{sr}\gamma _{{m th}}} \over {\Omega _{sr}P_c}}} ight)^n{m e}^{ - km_{sr}\gamma _{{m th}}/\Omega _{sr}P_c} \cr & \quad 	imes \Gamma \lpar m_{ar} + lpar \left({\displaystyle{{m_{ar}} \over {\Omega _{ar}}} + \displaystyle{{jm_{br}} \over {\Omega _{br}}}} ight)^{ - \lpar m_{ar} + lpar }\comma \; } \eqno\lpar 31par $$χab2(γth)=∑k=01∑n=0k(msr−1)∑j=01∑l=0j(mbr−1)(−1)k+jωnkωljΓ(mar)×marΩarmarmbrΩbrlmsrγthΩsrPcne−kmsrγth/ΩsrPc×Γ(mar+l)marΩar+jmbrΩbr−(mar+l),
with $	ilde 
u = 
u \gamma _{{m th}}^2 m_{rd}/P_cQ\Omega _{rd}$ν~=νγth2mrd/PcQΩrd, $	ilde m_{sr} = m_{sr} - s - t$m~sr=msr−s−t, $	ilde \kappa = \lpar m_{ar}/\Omega _{ar}par + \lpar \kappa m_{br}/\Omega _{br}par + \lpar 
u m_{rd}\gamma _{{m th}}/\Omega _{rd}Qpar $κ~=(mar/Ωar)+(κmbr/Ωbr)+(νmrdγth/ΩrdQ), $	ilde p = m_{ar} + m_{sr} + 2p + 2l - s - t - 1$p~=mar+msr+2p+2l−s−t−1, and $	ilde m_{ar} = m_{ar} + p + l$m~ar=mar+p+l.

statement.label: Proof
statement.p:
From (28), we can see that the terms in $\chi _{ab}^{{\rm Sec}} \lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\rpar $χabSec(γth) are dependent due to existence of a common RV $Y_{ar}$Yar. Therefore, we first obtain conditional expression $\chi _{ab}^{{\rm Sec}} \lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\vert Y_{ar}\rpar $χabSec(γth|Yar), conditioned on $Y_{ar} = y$Yar=y, as
(32)
$$\chi _{ab}^{{\rm Sec}} \lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\vert Y_{ar}\rpar = {\rm Pr}\left[{Y_{rd_n} \lt \displaystyle{{P_c\gamma _{{\rm th}}yY_{sr}} \over {QP_cY_{sr} - Q\gamma _{{\rm th}}}}} \right]{\rm Pr}\left[{Y_{br} \lt y} \right]\comma \; \eqno\lpar 32\rpar $$χabSec(γth|Yar)=PrYrdn<PcγthyYsrQPcYsr−QγthPrYbr<y,
which can be evaluated as
(33)
$$\eqalign{\chi _{ab}^{{\rm Sec}} \lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\vert Y_{ar}\rpar & =\underbrace{{F_{Y_{br}}\lpar y\rpar \int_{\gamma _{{\rm th}}/P_c}^\infty F_{Y_{rd_n}}\left({\displaystyle{{P_c\gamma _{{\rm th}}yw} \over {QP_cw - Q\gamma _{{\rm th}}}}} \right)f_{Y_{sr}}\lpar w\rpar \; {\rm d}w}}_{{\chi _{ab}^1 \lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\vert Y_{ar}\rpar }} \cr & \quad + \underbrace{{F_{Y_{sr}}\left({\displaystyle{{\gamma _{{\rm th}}} \over {P_c}}} \right)F_{Y_{br}}\lpar y\rpar }}_{{\chi _{ab}^2 \lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\vert Y_{ar}\rpar }}.} \eqno\lpar 33\rpar $$χabSec(γth|Yar)=FYbr(y)∫γth/Pc∞FYrdnPcγthywQPcw−QγthfYsr(w)dw⏟χab1(γth|Yar)+FYsrγthPcFYbr(y)⏟χab2(γth|Yar).
In (33), solving $\chi _{ab}^1 \lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\vert Y_{ar}\rpar $χab1(γth|Yar) with the use of involved CDF and PDF, and integrating (with change of variable after applying binomial expansion [23, eq. 1.111]), we get
(34)
$$\eqalign{\chi _{ab}^1 \lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\vert Y_{ar}\rpar & =2F_{Y_{br}}\lpar y\rpar \sum\limits_{\nu = 0}^1 \sum\limits_{p = 0}^{\nu \lpar m_{rd} - 1\rpar } \sum\limits_{t = 0}^p \sum\limits_{s = 0}^{m_{sr} - 1} \displaystyle{{{\lpar - 1\rpar }^\nu \omega _p^\nu {\cal C}_t^p } \over {\Gamma \lpar m_{sr}\rpar }} \cr & \quad \times {\cal C}_s^{m_{sr} - 1} \left({\displaystyle{{m_{sr}} \over {\Omega _{sr}}}} \right)^{m_{sr}}\left({\displaystyle{{\gamma _{{\rm th}}} \over {P_c}}} \right)^{s + t}{\rm e}^{ - \left[{\lpar \nu ym_{rd}\gamma _{{\rm th}}/Q\Omega _{rd}\rpar + \lpar m_{sr}\gamma _{{\rm th}}/\Omega _{sr}P_c\rpar } \right]} \cr & \quad \times \left({\displaystyle{{m_{rd}\gamma _{{\rm th}}y} \over {\Omega _{rd}Q}}} \right)^p\left({\displaystyle{{\tilde \nu \Omega _{sr}y} \over {m_{sr}}}} \right)^{{\tilde m}_{sr}/2}{\cal K}_{{\tilde m}_{sr}}\left({2\sqrt {\displaystyle{{\tilde \nu m_{sr}y} \over {\Omega _{sr}}}} } \right).} \eqno\lpar 34\rpar $$χab1(γth|Yar)=2FYbr(y)∑ν=01∑p=0ν(mrd−1)∑t=0p∑s=0msr−1(−1)νωpνCtpΓ(msr)×Csmsr−1msrΩsrmsrγthPcs+te−(νymrdγth/QΩrd)+(msrγth/ΩsrPc)×mrdγthyΩrdQpν~Ωsrymsrm~sr/2Km~sr2ν~msryΩsr.
Further, the term $\chi _{ab}^2 \lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\vert Y_{ar}\rpar $χab2(γth|Yar) in (33) can be obtained as
(35)
$$\eqalign{\chi _{ab}^2 \lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\vert Y_{ar}\rpar & =\sum\limits_{k = 0}^1 \sum\limits_{n = 0}^{k\lpar m_{sr} - 1\rpar } \sum\limits_{j = 0}^1 \sum\limits_{l = 0}^{j\lpar m_{br} - 1\rpar } \lpar - 1\rpar ^{k + j}\omega _n^k \omega _l^j \cr & \quad \times \left({\displaystyle{{m_{br}y} \over {\Omega _{br}}}} \right)^l\left({\displaystyle{{m_{sr}\gamma _{{\rm th}}} \over {\Omega _{sr}P_c}}} \right)^n{\rm e}^{ - \left({\lpar km_{sr}\gamma _{{\rm th}}/\Omega _{sr}P_c\rpar + \lpar jm_{br}y/\Omega _{br}\rpar } \right)}.} \eqno\lpar 35\rpar $$χab2(γth|Yar)=∑k=01∑n=0k(msr−1)∑j=01∑l=0j(mbr−1)(−1)k+jωnkωlj×mbryΩbrlmsrγthΩsrPcne−(kmsrγth/ΩsrPc)+(jmbry/Ωbr).
Now, by taking expectation of $\chi _{ab}^1 \lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\vert Y_{ar}\rpar $χab1(γth|Yar) and $\chi _{ab}^2 \lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\vert Y_{ar}\rpar $χab2(γth|Yar) over $Y_{ar}$Yar using its PDF, one can obtain $\chi _{ab}^1 \lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\rpar $χab1(γth) and $\chi _{ab}^2 \lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\rpar $χab2(γth) as given in (30) and (31), respectively. Finally, with these, the $\chi _{ab}^{{\rm Sec}} \lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\rpar $χabSec(γth) in (29) can be computed.□

sec.p: Next, by following Lemma 3, the expression of $\chi _{ba}^{{\rm Sec}} \lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\rpar $χbaSec(γth) can be derived which would be the same as obtained for $\chi _{ab}^{{\rm Sec}} \lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\rpar $χabSec(γth) in (29) with indices $\lcub a\comma \; b\rcub ${a,b} interchanged.

Thus, with the use of $\chi _{ab}^{{\rm Sec}} \lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\rpar $χabSec(γth) and $\chi _{ba}^{{\rm Sec}} \lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\rpar $χbaSec(γth) in (28) and substituting the result alongwith (26) into (25), the OP of secondary system ${\cal P}_{{\rm out}}^{{\rm Sec}} \lpar \gamma _{{\rm th}}\rpar $PoutSec(γth) can be finally evaluated.

sec.title: Average error probability
sec.p:
To derive the average error probability of secondary system, the CDF $F_{\Lambda _{{\rm eq}}}^{{\rm Sec}} \lpar x\rpar $FΛeqSec(x) corresponding to equivalent SINR $\Lambda _{{\rm eq}}{\rm \triangleq }\max \left({\Lambda _{sd_{n^ \ast }}\comma \; \Lambda _{rd_{n^ \ast }}} \right)$Λeq≜maxΛsdn∗,Λrdn∗ can be readily evaluated by replacing $\gamma _{{\rm th}}$γth with x in (25) and is given by
(36)
$$F_{\Lambda _{{\rm eq}}}^{{\rm Sec}} \lpar x\rpar = \left[{F_{\Lambda _{sd_n}}\lpar x\rpar } \right]^NF_{\Lambda _{rd_n}}\lpar x\rpar .\eqno\lpar 36\rpar $$FΛeqSec(x)=FΛsdn(x)NFΛrdn(x).
Here, $F_{\Lambda _{sd_n}}\lpar x\rpar $FΛsdn(x) can be obtained from (26) and $F_{\Lambda _{rd_n}}\lpar x\rpar $FΛrdn(x) from (28). With this, the average error probability can be written as
(37)
$$\eqalign{{\cal P}_e^{{\rm Sec}} & =\underbrace{{\displaystyle{\alpha \over 2}\sqrt {\displaystyle{\eta \over \pi }} \int_0^\infty \displaystyle{{\exp \lpar - \eta x\rpar } \over {\sqrt x }}{\left[{F_{\Lambda _{sd_n}}\lpar x\rpar } \right]}^N\chi _{ab}^{{\rm Sec}} \lpar x\rpar \; {\rm d}x}}_{{{\cal P}_{e_{ab}}^{{\rm Sec}} }} \cr & \quad + \underbrace{{\displaystyle{\alpha \over 2}\sqrt {\displaystyle{\eta \over \pi }} \int_0^\infty \displaystyle{{\exp \lpar - \eta x\rpar } \over {\sqrt x }}{\left[{F_{\Lambda _{sd_n}}\lpar x\rpar } \right]}^N\chi _{ba}^{{\rm Sec}} \lpar x\rpar \; {\rm d}x}}_{{{\cal P}_{e_{ba}}^{{\rm Sec}} }}\comma \; } \eqno\lpar 37\rpar $$PeSec=α2ηπ∫0∞exp⁡(−ηx)xFΛsdn(x)NχabSec(x)dx⏟PeabSec+α2ηπ∫0∞exp⁡(−ηx)xFΛsdn(x)NχbaSec(x)dx⏟PebaSec,
where ${\cal P}_{e_{ab}}^{{\rm Sec}} $PeabSec is as derived in the following Lemma.

statement.label: Lemma 4
Proof
statement.p:
For deriving ${\cal P}_{e_{ab}}^{{\rm Sec}} $PeabSec, we first need to obtain $\chi _{ab}^{{\rm Sec}} \lpar x\rpar $χabSec(x). From (28), the conditional expression $\chi _{ab}^{{\rm Sec}} \lpar x\vert Y_{ar}\rpar $χabSec(x|Yar) conditioned on $Y_{ar} = y$Yar=y can be represented as
(39)
$$\chi _{ab}^{{\rm Sec}} \lpar x\vert Y_{ar}\rpar = {\rm Pr}\left[{\displaystyle{{Y_1Y_2} \over {Y_1 + Y_2}} \lt x} \right]{\rm Pr}\left[{Y_{br} \lt y} \right]\comma \; \eqno\lpar 39\rpar $$χabSec(x|Yar)=PrY1Y2Y1+Y2<xPrYbr<y,
where $Y_1 = Q\lpar Y_{rd}/y\rpar $Y1=Q(Yrd/y) and $Y_2 = P_cY_{sr}$Y2=PcYsr. Using the fact that $\lpar XY/\lpar X + Y\rpar \rpar \lt \min \lpar X\comma \; Y\rpar $(XY/(X+Y))<min(X,Y), we can write
(40)
$$\eqalign{{\rm Pr}\left[{\displaystyle{{Y_1Y_2} \over {Y_1 + Y_2}} \lt x} \right]\simeq & {\rm Pr}\left[{\min \lpar Y_1\comma \; Y_2\rpar \lt x} \right]\cr \simeq & 1 - \lsqb 1 - F_{Y_1}\lpar x\rpar \rsqb \lsqb 1 - F_{Y_2}\lpar x\rpar \rsqb .} \eqno\lpar 40\rpar $$PrY1Y2Y1+Y2<x≃Prmin(Y1,Y2)<x≃1−[1−FY1(x)][1−FY2(x)].
It is worth mentioning that such an upper bound can be treated as tight approximation over entire range of operating SNR. Furthermore, substituting CDFs $F_{Y_1}\lpar x\rpar $FY1(x), $F_{Y_2}\lpar x\rpar $FY2(x) in (40) and obtained result in (39) alongwith CDF of $Y_{br}$Ybr, and then averaging over $Y_{ar}$Yar with its PDF, we get
(41)
$$\eqalign{\chi _{ab}^{{\rm Sec}} \lpar x\rpar \simeq & \sum\limits_{\nu = 0}^1 \sum\limits_{\mu = 0}^1 \sum\limits_{l = 0}^{\nu \lpar m_{rd} - 1\rpar } \sum\limits_{n = 0}^{\nu \lpar m_{sr} - 1\rpar } \sum\limits_{s = 0}^{\mu \lpar m_{br} - 1\rpar } \displaystyle{{{\lpar - 1\rpar }^{\nu + \mu }\omega _l^\nu } \over {\Gamma \lpar m_{ar}\rpar }} \cr & \quad \times \omega _n^\nu \omega _s^\mu \Gamma \lpar \tilde l\rpar \left({\displaystyle{{m_{ar}} \over {\Omega _{ar}}}} \right)^{m_{ar}}\left({\displaystyle{{m_{br}} \over {\Omega _{br}}}} \right)^s\left({\displaystyle{{m_{rd}} \over {\Omega _{rd}Q}}} \right)^l \cr & \quad \times \left({\displaystyle{{m_{sr}} \over {\Omega _{sr}P_c}}} \right)^n\displaystyle{{x^{l + n}{\rm e}^{ - \nu m_{sr}x/\Omega _{sr}P_c}} \over {{\left({\lpar \nu m_{rd}x/\Omega _{rd}Q\rpar + \lpar \mu m_{br}/\Omega _{br}\rpar + \lpar m_{ar}/\Omega _{ar}\rpar } \right)}^{\tilde l}}}.} \eqno\lpar 41\rpar $$χabSec(x)≃∑ν=01∑μ=01∑l=0ν(mrd−1)∑n=0ν(msr−1)∑s=0μ(mbr−1)(−1)ν+μωlνΓ(mar)×ωnνωsμΓ(l~)marΩarmarmbrΩbrsmrdΩrdQl×msrΩsrPcnxl+ne−νmsrx/ΩsrPc(νmrdx/ΩrdQ)+(μmbr/Ωbr)+(mar/Ωar)l~.
On plugging (41) in (37), while representing the term in denominator with Meijer's G-function as done in (23), and then performing the required integration, we get ${\cal P}_{e_{ab}}^{{\rm Sec}} $PeabSec as given in (38). Similarly, ${\cal P}_{e_{ba}}^{{\rm Sec}} $PebaSec can be obtained by interchanging indices $\lcub a\comma \; b\rcub ${a,b} in ${\cal P}_{e_{ab}}^{{\rm Sec}} $PeabSec. Finally, using ${\cal P}_{e_{ab}}^{{\rm Sec}} $PeabSec and ${\cal P}_{e_{ba}}^{{\rm Sec}} $PebaSec, the average error probability can be evaluated from (37).□

sec.p: From the preceding analysis, we can infer that although the performance of secondary system depends on the parameters of primary channels, it is greatly influenced by the direct $C_s - C_{d_n}$Cs−Cdn channel parameters and number of SU destinations N due to the exploitation of multiuser diversity.

sec.title: Average system throughput
sec.p:
In this section, we evaluate another important performance metric called average system throughput [27, 28] to characterise the mean spectral efficiency of the considered system. Herein, we consider ${\cal R}_{\cal P}$RP and ${\cal R}_{\cal S}$RS as the target data rates of the primary and secondary systems, respectively. As the complete transmission of CRSS takes place in two time phases, the overall system throughput ${\cal R}_{\cal T}$RT can be represented as
(42)
$${\cal R}_{\cal T} = \displaystyle{{{\cal R}_{\cal P}} \over 2}\left[{1 - {\cal P}_{{\rm out}}^{{\rm Pri}} \lpar \gamma _P\rpar } \right]+ \displaystyle{{{\cal R}_{\cal S}} \over 2}\left[{1 - {\cal P}_{{\rm out}}^{{\rm Sec}} \lpar \gamma _S\rpar } \right]\comma \; \eqno\lpar 42\rpar $$RT=RP21−PoutPri(γP)+RS21−PoutSec(γS),
with $\gamma _P = 2^{{\cal R}_{\cal P}} - 1$γP=2RP−1 and $\gamma _S = 2^{2{\cal R}_{\cal S}} - 1$γS=22RS−1. Here, the overall throughput ${\cal R}_{\cal T}$RT for the CRSS can be readily obtained by substituting ${\cal P}_{{\rm out}}^{{\rm Pri}} \lpar \gamma _P\rpar $PoutPri(γP) and ${\cal P}_{{\rm out}}^{{\rm Sec}} \lpar \gamma _S\rpar $PoutSec(γS) from (14) and (25), respectively, into (42).

sec.title: Numerical and simulation results
sec.p: In this section, we present the numerical and simulation results to validate our theoretical analysis for considered CRSS. For this, we consider a two-dimensional (x, y) topology, whereby the primary network nodes $T_a$Ta and $T_b$Tb are located at (0, 0.5) and (1, 0.5) respectively. Whereas, the secondary nodes $C_s$Cs, $C_{d_n}$Cdn, and $C_r$Cr are placed at (0, 0), (1, 0), and (0.5, d), respectively. We set $\gamma _{{\rm th}} = 0 \; {\rm dB}$γth=0dB, $P_c = 5\; {\rm dB}$Pc=5dB, and assume $d_{ij}$dij as the distance between corresponding links so that $\Omega _{ij} = d_{ij}^{ - 4} $Ωij=dij−4.

In Fig. 2, we plot the OP curves for primary system versus power P under different fading parameters $\lpar m_{ar}\comma \; m_{br}\rpar $(mar,mbr), and relay locations. We also set Q = 5 dB and $m_{sr} = 2$msr=2. First, we found that the analytical curves are in perfect match with the simulation results. From various curves, it is apparent that the outage performance of two-way primary system improves as fading parameters $\lpar m_{ar}\comma \; m_{br}\rpar $(mar,mbr) increase from (2, 2) to (3, 3). Furthermore, we examine the impact of relay position d on the performance of primary system. Clearly, the performance of primary system degrades as d changes from 0.5 to 0.4. This is due to the increase in interference power level at the PU terminals since the relay moves closer to the SU transmitter $C_s$Cs. On the contrary, performance of primary system improves when relay moves away from $C_s$Cs, i.e. when d increases. Fig. 2
Outage probability of primary system with varying d and fading parameters

To investigate the effectiveness of the proposed CRSS, we also compare the performance of primary system with bidirectional DT only (i.e. without relay sharing) in Fig. 3. Herein, we obtain the outage performance of DT only through simulations by assuming $\lpar m_{ab}\comma \; \Omega _{ab}\rpar $(mab,Ωab) as the parameters for direct channel between $T_a$Ta and $T_b$Tb. By setting $\Omega _{ab} = 1$Ωab=1, we plot OP curves of DT only for the cases $m_{ab} = 1$mab=1 and $m_{ab} = 3$mab=3. Comparing the curve for $m_{ab} = 1$mab=1 with $\lpar m_{ar}\comma \; m_{br}\rpar = \lpar 1\comma \; 2\rpar $(mar,mbr)=(1,2) and Q = 5 dB at fixed relay location d = 0.8, we can see that the considered CRSS outperforms DT only in terms of primary system performance. However, the performance of former improves significantly when relay links become better, i.e. $\lpar m_{ar}\comma \; m_{br}\rpar = \lpar 2\comma \; 2\rpar $(mar,mbr)=(2,2). Note that, depending upon the relay location d, there may be instances where the performance of CRSS is poorer than the DT only (e.g. refer the case for d = 0.5 when $m_{ab} = 3$mab=3, $\lpar m_{ar}\comma \; m_{br}\rpar = \lpar 3\comma \; 3\rpar $(mar,mbr)=(3,3)). Importantly, even for such cases, the performance of CRSS can be made better if the relay location is chosen appropriately, i.e. d = 0.7. Fig. 3
Outage probability of primary system with or without relay sharing

Fig. 4 shows the average error probability curves versus P for primary system considering BPSK modulation. Setting $P_c = Q = 10\; {\rm dB}$Pc=Q=10dB, it is apparent that the error performance improves as the fading severity reduces. Also, as expected, the variation in d affects the performance significantly. As the relay moves away from the SU source (i.e. as the value of d increases), the interference from SU signal weakens and thereby the error performance improves. Fig. 4
Average error probability of primary system for BPSK with varying d and fading parameters

In Fig. 5, we investigate the outage performance of secondary system for the proposed CRSS model. Setting $\lpar m_{ar}\comma \; m_{br}\rpar = \lpar 2\comma \; 1\rpar $(mar,mbr)=(2,1) and N = 4, we plot OP curves against Q for various fading parameters $\lpar m_{sd}\comma \; m_{sr}\comma \; m_{rd}\rpar $(msd,msr,mrd). We can see that the simulation results are perfectly matching with the analytical curves. From these curves, one can observe that the outage performance of secondary system improves with the increase of parameters $\lpar m_{sd}\comma \; m_{sr}\comma \; m_{rd}\rpar $(msd,msr,mrd). This is expected because of the improved fading conditions of the direct and/or relaying paths. More importantly, referring the cases $\lpar m_{sd}\comma \; m_{sr}\comma \; m_{rd}\rpar = \lpar 3\comma \; 1\comma \; 2\rpar $(msd,msr,mrd)=(3,1,2) and (3,2,1), we infer that the performance of secondary system is dominated by the fading condition of the first hop ($C_s \to C_r$Cs→Cr link) when compared with the second hop ($C_r \to C_{d_n}$Cr→Cdn link). Furthermore, at high Q, secondary system performance appears to be saturated, as SU transmit power $P_c$Pc is kept fixed. Fig. 5
Outage probability of secondary system with various fading parameters

Fig. 6 illustrates the impact of relay location d and number of SU destinations N on the performance of secondary system. Here, it can be observed that the performance of secondary system improves as d changes from 0.7 to 0.5 (or 0.3). This is attributed to the fact that as the relay shifts near to the SU terminals (i.e. $C_s$Cs and $C_{d_n}$Cdn), the attenuation due to path loss lessens. Moreover, the secondary system performance improves notably with the increase of N. This could be due to the exploitation of multiuser diversity in the secondary system. Fig. 6
Outage probability of secondary system with varying d and N

In Fig. 7, we plot the average error probability curves versus Q for the secondary system. With $\lpar m_{ar}\comma \; m_{br}\rpar = \lpar 1\comma \; 1\rpar $(mar,mbr)=(1,1), we investigate the error performance with various fading parameters for BPSK modulation. From the curves, it is apparent that for lower values of Q, the error performance remains unchanged for the same $m_{sd}$msd. While the performance improves at high Q with better channel conditions. Furthermore, increase in N also aids in the performance because of multiuser scheduling. Fig. 7
Average error probability of secondary system for BPSK with various fading parameters

Fig. 8 demonstrates the average throughput offered by CRSS against Q. Here, we set $P_s = 10\; {\rm dB}$Ps=10dB, P = 15 dB, and $m_{ij} = 3$mij=3, where $i \in \lcub a\comma \; b\comma \; s\comma \; r\rcub $i∈{a,b,s,r}, $j \in \lcub r\comma \; d\rcub $j∈{r,d} and $i \ne j$i≠j. By assuming ${\cal R}_{\cal P} = {\cal R}_{\cal S} = {\cal R}_{\cal T}/2$RP=RS=RT/2, it can be seen from the respective curves that when the target rate is kept low as ${\cal R}_{\cal T} = 1\; {\rm bps}/{\rm Hz}$RT=1bps/Hz, the achievable rate of CRSS rapidly approaches the target rate. While for the higher target rate such as ${\cal R}_{\cal T} = 3\; {\rm bps}/{\rm Hz}$RT=3bps/Hz, the average throughput is limited for lower values of Q. However, as the value of Q increases, the average throughput offered by CRSS tends to approach the target rate. Fig. 8
Average throughput of overall system

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this paper, we analysed the performance of a CRSS with bidirectional primary communications employing AF-based MABC protocol. We derived the closed-form expressions of OP and average error probability for both primary and secondary systems under Nakagami-m fading channels. We have also investigated the average system throughput offered by the CRSS. Our results illustrated that, leveraging with two-way primary communications, the proposed CRSS offers higher spectral efficiency. Moreover, by exploiting the advantages of multiuser cooperation, reliability of SU communication is also improved significantly. Finally, we validated our theoretical developments using Monte Carlo simulations.
